Wall St. from Broad St.

723852f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723848f-a.text:
Wall Street, east from a point to the east of Broad Street. In the right center is the distinctive Merchants Exchange. This occupies the entire block frontage from William to Hanover Street's. It is later to become the U. S. Custom House. On their removal to the new Custom House at Bowling Green, the National City Bank will take over. Note the scaffold suspended at the corner.
About 1860
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723848f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723862f-a.text:
Wall Street, west across Broad & Nassau Streets, to Broadway. At the latter point appears the dominant (then) feature, Trinity Church. at the right margin are the steps of the U. S. Sub Treasury prior to the erection of the Washington statue there in 1883. Beyond same is a five story building at the N. W. corner of Nassau Street. This was increased two stories in heighth and became the Manhattan Trust Co. The structure on the left center housing "Kiernants" is the predecessor of the Wilks Building.
Between 1872.80
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Ng ~2077
723862f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723863f-a.text:
Wall Street, west across Broad & Nassau Street's, to Broadway. At the latter point is the dominant Trinity Church. The four corners in the center are occupied by, the Drexel Morgan Bldg., the Kiernan Telegraphic Agency, the 5 story (later 7) structure soon to be the Manhattan Trust Co. home and the U. S. Sub Treasury. Note the absence of the Washington statue on the steps of the latter.
N4eg e 33o
Between 1872280
(2)
Wall Street and at the Pead of Street may be seen the )pires of Trinity Church. At the rigght of picture may be seen the Sub-Treasury Building,East Side, an8 tho statue of George WWashington,corner of Wall street and
Nassau.
No date,nor record.

This shows the Gillender Building, completed in 1897 and demolished in 1910 for the Bankers Trust Bldg at Broad and Wall.  Since there are no cars, I'd guess 1897.
JHale 5-27-15
723863f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723865f-a.text:
Wall Street, west from Broad &: Nassau Streets, to Broadway, showing at the 1atter point, Trinity Church. New Street intersects at the left. Note the absence of the National Bank of the Republic (Fort Sherman) that was erected in 1880 at the N.E. corner of Broadway. A comparison with other views leads the writer to conclude that this photo dates between 1872-1880.
Between 1872-1883

716840f-a.text:
Broad Street, west side, south from, but not including Wall Street. Building shown on the extreme right, is the old N.Y. Stock Exchange. The building with the tower, is the N.Y. Produce Exchange.
About 1885.
New York Edison Co.

716861f-a.text:
Broad Street, west side, south from, but not including Wall, to, but not including Beaver Streets. 3uilding shown on the extreme right, is the old Stock Exchango. In the background appears the tower of the N.Y. Produce Exchange.
About 1885.

716884f-a.folder: Broad Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

716834f.text:
Broad Street, south from Wall Street,
showing mainly the westerly side of this thoroughfare. To the left, center, and right respectively wre, the old Mills Building (replaced in 1926 by the 38-story Equitable Trust Co. Building), the Produce Exchange (distinctive tower wtop) and the New York Stock Exchange Building. Adjoining the latter is the renovated 6-story building adjoining the corner structure. These were subsequently demolished and their site improved by w larger building and which in time was replaced by the north wing of the Stock Exchange.
See King's Handbook of New York (1893),
page 155 for a slightly later view.
Between 1889-1893
Gift Thru New York Historical Society
716834f.folder: Broad Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

723896f.text:
Wall Street, west across Nassau Street, showing prominently the J. 9Q. A. Ward statue of Washington on the U.S. Sub Treasury steps . To the left center is Trinity Church at Broadway. Between these features appear the dark National Bank of the Republic and the white marble Manhattan Trust Co. home. The newly erected Mortimer Bldg. is at
the left margin at New Street.
1890
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Ne.~2S41
723896f.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723885f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

716835f-a.text:
Broad Street, south from Wall Street, showing prominently the westerly side of this important
thoroughfare.
At the extreme right is the Wilks Building separated from the New York Stock Exchange Building by a renovated (between 1889-1893) five-story structure. Towering above same is the graceful Mackey Building. The Johnston Building is to the south,while beyond appears the dim outline of the Produce Exchange. Note
beteeen these the Edison Building.
At the left margin is the DRexel Building and its
adjoining Mills structure.
About 1893
Gift of Urbrock CollecTion
716835f-a.folder: Broad Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

716862f-a.text:

723864f-a.text:
Wall Street, west across Broad (left) and Nassau (right) Street's, to Broadway, showing the westerly extremity of this financial thoroughfare headed by Trinity Church. At the four corners in the foreground are, the Drexel Morgan & Co. Building, the Wilks Building, the Manhattan Trust Co. Building and the U. S. Sub Treasury. Adjoining the latter is the old Assay Office. To the right of the Church is the darkened National Bank of the Republic popularly known
as "Fort Sherman".
1894
Copyrisht, 1894
J. S. Johnston, phoo
Girt or Urbrock Collection

716842f-a.text:
Broad Street, west side, south from Wall Street. At the left and right margins respectively are, the Drexel, Morgan & Co. Dldg. and the Tew York Stock Exchange. Two doors beyond the latter is Commercial Cable ('ackey) Bldg. under constructio3. Separating this and the Johnston Bldg. are two small structures on this side of Exchange Place. These will shortly provide the site for the Blair Bldg. This photo is an enlargement from an origihnal lantern slide.
Circa 1896
Gift of Russell Freeman
ew York Public Library

723890f-a.text:
Wall Street, at the N. E. corner of Nassau Street, showing the U. S. Sub Treasury steps and the J. Q. A. Ward statue of Washington thereupon. The inscription reads " Erected By Voluntary Subscription Under The Auspices Of The Chamber Of Commerce Of The State Of
New York, November 26, 1883."
About 1900
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723890f-a.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

716833f.text:
Broad Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of Wall Street, showing the facade of the New York Stock Exchange
Building.
The center figure represents "Integrity." On the right the groups represent "Frimitive Agriculture and the Products of the Soil' and "Mining.' On the loft, "votive Power, Scientific and Mechanical Appliances" and "the
Designer and Mechanic."
This appeared in the Evening Mail Illustrated Saturday Magazine of June 18, 1904 several days after
the unveiling ceremonies.
June, 1904
Gift of Urbrock Collection
NVEG ~ EE35
716833f.folder: Broad Street & Wall Street, Manhattan, NY

723857f-a.text:
Wall Street (left), at the S. E. corner of Broad Street (right), showing the Morgan Drexel &: Co. building decorated for the Hudson Fulton Celebration. At the left margin is the U. S. Sub Treasury at the N. E. corner of Nassau Street.
September 30, 1909
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723857f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723879f-a.text:
Vall Street, at the N.W. corner of Nassau Street, showing AEM4er  at that location, the Gillenden Building. This was replaced by the 32 story Bankers Trust Company Building. This property is reported to have brought one of the highest prices in New York real estate dealings, 825 per square foot. The writer believes that the vantage point for the photographer is atop the former Schmerhorn Building on Broadway and that he is viewing
southeastward.
April 28, 1910
Gift of Albert A. Volk Company
A. R. Bond
Irving Underhill
723879f-a.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723905f-a.text:
Nassau Street, west side, from Wall (left) to Pine (right) Streets, showing the new Bankers Trust Building and the adjoining Hanover National Bank Building. The latter is at the S. W. corner of Nassau and Pine Streets. This site, in conjunction with the Astor Building (left margin) was absorbed into the later enlarged
Bankers Trust Building.
Note the Singer Tower at the right.
1911
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Copyright 1911
George P. Hall and Son

723861f-a.text:
Wall Street (center of No. 1) and vicinity, at Proad and Nassau Streets, as viewed westward from the Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Bldg. Prominently shown is the 32 storied Bankers Trust Co; at the N.W. corner of Wall and Nassau Streets. Adjoining same on the latter front is the 22 story Hanover National Bank Bldg. To the right of the latter in View No. 2 appears the 38 storied Equitable Bldg. on Broadway. At the margin is the Bank of N.Y. and Trust Co. with a golden eagle atop thereof. The intervening space between this and the aforementioned Bankers Trust Co. Bldg. will shortly provide a base for the 7O storied Bank of Manhattan.
May 13, 1929.
Views 1 and 2
P.L. Sperr

To the right of the latter in View No. 2 appears the 38 storied Equitable Bldg. on Broadway. At the margin is the Bank of N.Y. and Trust Co. with a golden eagle atop thereof. 723907f-a.text:
(1)
Wall Street, north side, adjoining and east of the N.E.
corner of Nassau Street.
May 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a view point slightly further westward and showing a more inclusive view. The 4-story structure on the left is the U.S. Assay Office, No. 30-k2 and adjoins the U.S. Sub Treasury (at the corner). Under demolition are Nos. 34-36 (former Gallatin National Bank) and 38, which in conjunction with the balance of buildings on this block, will form the 70-storied Bank of Manhattan Building. On the right appears the entrance to J.P. Morgan and Co. Building. at the S.E. corner of Broad and
Wall Streets.
May 12. 1929.
L. Sperr.

723846f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723849f-a.text:
Wall Street, south side, east from Broad Street. At the left is the old Custom House that originally was the Merchants Exchange. 1t is later to be occupied by the National City Bank. Cn the right margin are the buildings that were removec for the ornate Drexel Morgan &. Co. Bldg of 1872.
About 1864
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Neg e: 372
723849f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723851f-a.text:
Wall Street, at the S. E. corner of Broad Street, showing the site of the Drexel Morgan & Co. Bldg. of 1872 prior to the improvement. Wall Street is on the left, while Broad Street is on the right. Incidently the Mills Bldg. was erected on the latter thoroughfare adjacent to the
aforementioned structure.
About 1866
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723851f-a.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723855f.text:
Wall Street, south from Broad Street.  On the right is the old J. P. Morgan and Company Building. On the left is the Sub-Treasury.

Ewing Galloway
no date

Neg #329
723855f.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723858f.text:
Wall Street (left) east from Broad (right) to Hanover Streets, showing the strtcture at the S.E. corner of the first point under demolition. J. B. Morgan and Co. occupy a 4-story structure at this location today (1938). On the right appears the east side of Broad Street, south to and including Exchange Place with the 10-story Mills Building (now the site of the 38-story Ecquitable Trust Co. Building) at the N.E. corner of the latter point. Across the Place and at its S.E. corner is the 21story Broad Exchange Building. On the extreme left appears the Umited States Sub-Treasury Building. This set consists of a negative and a
positive.
May 12, 1913.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.
723858f.folder: Wall Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

723877f.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723878f-a.text:
Wall Street (right)at and adjoining the N. E. corner of Nassau Street (left), showing the U. S. Subtreasury and it's adjacent Assay Office. The latter was removed in 1916 and reconstructed in the American wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. On the left margin appears the 5 story Mechanics & Metals National Bank, occupying the Nassau Street frontage from Pine to Cedar Street's. This structure was subsequently replaced with the modern Chase National Bank Building.
Note the absense of the J. Q. A. Ward statue of Washington on the steps of the Sub Treasury.This work of art was unveild November 26, 1883, the day following Evacuation day.

Prior to 1883.

Gift of Urbrock Collection.
723878f-a.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723880f-a.text:
Wall Street, adjoining the N. E. corner of Nassau Street, showing the old U. S. Assay Office occupying this site. It was demolished in 1916 and portions removed to the American wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Bank of Manhattan Building inoludes this location today. A new Assay Office building was erected
at South Street and Old Slip.
Prior to 1916
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723880f-a.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723904f-a.text:
Wall Street, north side, at Nassau Street, showing progressively (from the right) the old U. S. Assay Office, the U. S. Sub Treasury and the Manhattan Trust Co. bldg. Towering over the latter is the American Surety Building that was erected between 1893-7 at Broadway and Pine St.
About 1900
Gift of Urbrock Collection
723904f-a.folder: Wall Street & Nassau Street, Manhattan, NY

723906f-a.text:
Wall Street, adjoining the N. E. corner of Nassau Street, showing the old U. S. Assay Office occupying this site. It was demolished in 1916 and portions removed to the American wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A new building housing the Assay Office was erected on South Street, at Old Slip.
Prior to 1916
Gift of Urbrock Collection
